column4: i have ubuntu installed on a 10gb drive.  i also have a 40gb drive that i want to put stuff on.  is there any way to do that?
mount the 40gb hard drive. what filesystem is it?
i don't know that its formated.  i think it has an old linux install on it.
grap GParted (or QTParted if you are on KDE) and format it
how should i make the new partitions?
however you want
ex2 file system?
primary or extended partition?
ok.  so its called /dev/hde1
now you need to mount it
sudo mount /dev/hde1 /media/hde1 (you can make a folder in /media with the name of the place you want to mount it on if you want)
mount point /media/hde1 does not exist
you have to create it then do   sudo mkdir /media/hde1
then do sudo mount /dev/hde1 /media/hde1 again
good deal.  so that should be visible there in my file system right?
want me to tell you how to add it to fstab?
no
how do i unmount that drive that i just mounted.  i want to change the mount point name to something different.
sudo umount /media/hde1
can the mount point be different than the name it displays under the icon.  for instance /home is displayed as Home Folder.
you can name the mountpoint whatever you want. just sudo mkdir /media/customnamehere then mount it /media/customnamehere

i guess what i'm saying is.  i want to keep the mount name simple without spaces and such for command purposes, but for it to display something different under the desktop icon.  either that or get rid of the desktop icon.
im sure there is, but im not sure off hand how to do it
